markdownRemark.excerpt: In this article I will be doing a quick review of 4 CS boooks I have been reading in 2020 - well, to be fair out of these 4 books, I have only completed one…
markdownRemark.html:
In this article I will be doing a quick review of 4 CS boooks I have been reading in 2020 - well, to be fair out of these 4 books, I have only completed one, and I have gone through less than the half for the others. Still, I already learned a lot, and I thought the start of this new year was a good opportunity to reflect on my learning.

The Elements of Computing Systems: Building a Modern Computer from First Principles (aka Nand to Tetris)

Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs

As far as I recall, I picked up this book for 2 reasons: I heard people say great things about it at RC, and it was marked as “readers also enjoyed” on the Nand to Tetris page in Goodreads.

This book contains a a MIT introductory course on programming, which puts an emphasis on two aspects:

  • “programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute”
  • What techniques can use to control the intellectual complexity of large software systems
  • what it is
  • what I think (at first a succession of toy exercises + not for beginners + love Lisp)

Types and Programming languages

Category Theory for the Progammer

frontmatter.title: Creating a lambda calculus interpreter - report
